case_vignette: An 11-year-old girl is brought to her primary care physician by her mother with complaints of constant lower abdominal pain and foul-smelling urine for the past 2 days. The patient has had several previous episodes of simple urinary tract infections in the past. Her vitals signs show mild tachycardia without fever. Physical examination reveals suprapubic tenderness without costovertebral angle tenderness on percussion. Urinalysis reveals positive leukocyte esterase and nitrite. Further questioning reveals that the patient does not use the school toilets and holds her urine all day until she gets home. When pressed further, she gets teary-eyed and starts to cry and complains that other girls will make fun of her if she uses the bathroom and will spread rumors to the teachers and her friends. She reports that though this has never happened in the past it concerns her a great deal.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Renal and Genitourinary System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have constant lower abdominal pain and my urine smells bad.
What is your age and sex?
I'm an 11-year-old girl.
Do you have any history of urinary tract infections or kidney problems?
Yes, I've had several urinary tract infections before.
Have you been taking any medications for your urinary tract infections? If so, what are they?
The case vignette does not provide information about whether I have been taking medications for my urinary tract infections or what they might be.
Understood. Does anyone in your family have a history of kidney or urinary problems?
The vignette does not mention any family history of kidney or urinary problems.
**Final Diagnosis:** Recurrent Urinary Tract Infection
